name: wtaniwe
displayName: WTANIWE - Writing Tool, An Integrated Writing Environment
description: Writing Tool, An Integrated Writing Environment

walkthroughs.title: Introduction to WTANIWE
walkthroughs.description: A broad overview of Writing Tool's major features.

steps.title: Organize Your Project by the Chapter
steps.description:
- The main impetus behind WANIWE's creation was the ability to organize my extremely fragmented WIP in an easier way.
- One of the main features of WTANIWE, therefore, is the outline tree, where users can get a clear overview of their progress.

steps.title: Organize Your Project by Text Fragments
steps.description:
- Instead of throwing all content of a chapter into a single text file, with WTANIWE you can organize the content of your work by smaller, chunkable, text fragments.
- Anywhere where you would insert a scene break in your work, just create a new text fragment and start with a fresh file.

steps.title: Organize Notes/Text Snippets for Each Chapter
steps.description:
- Another major motivation for WTANIWE was the ability to organize notes and snippets of text for each chapter in an easily organizable way.
- Instead of opening twenty different word documents at a time while scouring for that one piece of dialogue I wrote two months ago, and killing my computer in the process, I can place all notes for a project in one place.
- Just as with chapters, each text note (called snip by WTANIWE) can have multiple text fragments associated with it.

steps.title: Organize Snips for Project
steps.description:
- If you're like me, you have about a hundred tiny fragments of text laying around which have a loose place in your story but no solid chapter commitement yet.  Work Snips is a section of the Outline Tree where you can store all misc. text snippets with no solid home yet.
- Like Chapters and Chapter Snips, Work Snips can be separated into multiple text fragments.

steps.title: Write in Plain Text
steps.description:
- No wasting time for Microsoft to stir up twelve different processes to load one Word Document or for Google to serve you one fragment of your own project, all WTANIWE text files are stored in plain text on your own hard drive.
- All text stylings you would expect from word are available through a modified version of MarkDown which is more amenable to writing (and, admittedly less feature-rich).
- Surround text with asterisks (*) to italisize, hashtags (#) to bold, underscores (_) to underline, and tildes (~) to strike through.

steps.title: Highlight Problem Words or Phrases
steps.description:
- All people have crutch words and phrases that they over rely on when writing.
- When using the Word Watcher panel you can enter these words and phrases into the Word Watcher panel, and WTANIWE will highlight them for you.
- Use [regex](https://www.regex101.com) patterns to select text which fits a pattern instead of whole, known words.  (Such as the regex '[a-zA-Z]+ly' which captures all words that end in 'ly').
- Modify the colors in the Word Watcher panel to clearly separate each watched word in a visually distinctive way.

steps.title: Quickly Find Synonyms For Words
steps.description:
- Without leaving the VS Code window or moving your mouse whatsoever, you can get synonyms for any selected word or phrase by hitting ctrl+space over a selection.
- This will bring up an intellisense window of synonymous definitions.  Open a definition with enter, then select a synonym with enter again to replace the original.

steps.title: Quickly Navigate your Text
steps.description:
- Use built in writing-focused keybindings to quickly navigate over sentences, sentence fragments, and paragraphs.
- ctrl+[ / ctrl+] Jumps forward and backward through sentences.
- alt+[ / alt+] Jumps forward and backward through sentence fragments.
- ctrl+alt+[ / ctrl+alt+] Jumps forward and backward through paragraphs.

steps.title: Use Git to Track your Progress
steps.description:
- If you've downloaded this from VS Code, you probably know all about git so I won't waste your time explaining it.
- Git is the de facto source control management software in industry, so why not use it to track your WIP?

steps.title: Import Your Work
steps.description:
- WTANIWE makes it easy to import work from outside sources AND organize that work withing WTANIWE's outline.
- WTANIWE's importing tool is feature rich and has an entirely separate walkthrough that you can open now or browse through when you want to import

[Open Imports Walkthrough](command:wt.walkthroughs.openImports)

walkthroughs.title: Introduction to WTANIWE's Imports
walkthroughs.description: An in depth look at WTANIWE's imports feature

steps.title: Overview
steps.description:
- Overview of the Imports Pane: 
- Hit the folder icon in the imports view to open the folder where all your imported documents should go.
- Hit the refresh button to update the GUI.
- Hit the plus button to import all documents in the imports folder.
- Click on a single file to import just that file (or a folder to import all files in that folder).
- Before we continue, I recommend you open up some of the generic example docx files to familiarize yourself with the content of this walkthrough.

steps.title: Import a Single Chapter
steps.description:
- The most basic kind of imports are a single chapter, so let's start there.
- In the imports form, select the 'Chapter' output type.
- If you would like to separate the text into separate chapters based on scene breaks, then click on the 'Split the document?' checkbox and enter the pattern you use for scene breaks in the new text box.
- All separators in WTANIWE are based on regex.  Common scene separators may include three tildes (~~~), three newlines (\n\n\n), or a dot on a line (^\.$).
- To learn more about regexes, click [here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Guide/Regular_expressions/Cheatsheet).
- Test out your regexes [here](https://www.regex101.com).
- Don't forget to name your chapter as well!
- Test this out by importing the example document 'Example Single Chapter Import.docx' with the options seen here and you should see a new chapter in the outline tree with the title 'Bob 4 (Bob's No Good, Very Bad Day)' with four lorem ipsum-filled text fragments.

steps.title: Import Multiple Chapters
steps.description:
- To split a single document into multiple imported chapters, use the same steps as before but also select the 'Split on chapters?' checkbox.
- In the new text box that appears, enter the pattern you would like to use to separate your chapters.
- For example, if you separated your chapters in your imported document with the the text 'CH ###' on a new line between each chapter, enter the regex pattern 'CH \d+'.
- ('\d' indicates a number 0-9, '+' indicates one or more repetitions).
- To learn more about regexes, click [here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Guide/Regular_expressions/Cheatsheet).
- Test out your regexes [here](https://www.regex101.com).
- Don't forget to name your chapter as well!
- Test this out by importing the example document 'Example Multiple Chapter Import.docx' with the options seen here and you should see three new chapter in the outline tree with the titles 'Wow, so much new (imported) misery for Bob!' with two, one, and three lorem ipsum-filled text fragments respectively.

steps.title: Import a Single Chapter Snippet
steps.description:
- The other main import type is importing notes or text fragments into existing chapters.
- To import notes into chapters, select the 'Snip' output type.
- Check the 'Output into Chapter' checkbox to indicate that the destination of the notes is a chapter (and not uncategorized 'Work Snips').
- And, finally, in the drop down that appears, select the chapter that you would like to insert the snips into.
- Test this out by importing the example document 'Example Single Snip Import.docx' with the options seen here and you should see one new snip with four new lorem ipsum filled fragments in the selected chapter.

steps.title: Import a Single Work Snippet
steps.description:
- To import uncategorized notes -- or text fragments that do not have a chapter placement yet -- follow the same steps as before, but do no select to import into a specific chapter.
- Test this out by importing the example document 'Example Single Snip Import.docx' with the options seen here and you should see one new snip with four new lorem ipsum filled fragments in the work snips area.

steps.title: Import Multiple Text Snippets
steps.description:
- To import multiple text snippets from a single document, follow the same steps as the multiple chapters import description along with the single snip import instructions.
- Test this out by importing the example document 'Example Multiple Snip Import.docx' with the options seen here and you should see three new snips in the work snips area.

steps.title: Import Multiple Chapters with Unique Names
steps.description:
- One issue you may have noticed with the importing system so far is that whenever there are more than one imported item in single document, all the Outline Tree items that get produced have similarly patterned names.
- To fix this, you can assign names to specific sections of the inner items of split documents by using [regex capture groups](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Regular_expressions/Capturing_group) for capturing unique a part of the splitter pattern.  The part of the split text that is captured by the rightmost capture group in the splitter regex will be used as the title of the chapter.
- For example, the multiple chapters split step from earlier used the regex pattern 'CH \d+' to split the single document into multiple chapters.  But, if we changed the splitting pattern to surround the original pattern with parentheses: '(CH \d+)', we can utilize this capture group to assign unique names to each imported chapter.
- Test this out by importing the example document 'Example Single Chapter Import.docx' with the options seen here and you should see three chapters added with the names 'CH 1', 'CH 2', and 'CH 3' from the document.

steps.title: Import Text Snippets with Unique Names and Named Text Fragments
steps.description:
- A more detailed usage of splitter capture groups can be seen on the right.
- Use more complicated regex patterns such as the splitter '\[{3,}([^\]]*)\]{3,}' to match pairings of triple (or more) square brackets enclosing some (or none) generic text within.
- For example '\\[{3,}([^\\]\]*)\\]{3,}' matches the text '\[\[\[\[\[Title of the first snip\]\]\]' and uses 'Title of the first snip' as the title of the snip that follows.  It also matches '\[\[\[\[\[\[\[More brackets\]\]\]\]\]\]\]' or '\[\[\[Minimum Brackets\]\]\]' or even '\[\[\[\[\[[\]\]\]' with no title.
- In the example document 'Example Named Snips.docx' you can see two splitter patterns used: First the afformentioned pattern '\[{3,}([^\]]*)\]{3,}' to split snips, and also a new pattern '~{3,}([^~]*])~{3,}' which is very similar to that pattern except replace square brackets with tildes.
- See how the content of the example document corresponds to the imported Outline Tree items.
- Fragments without preceding '~~~Title~~~' separators recieve generic names 'Imported Fragment (###)' titles, whereas others get names like 'Title of the first fragment'.  Similarly, all the snips recieved names from between the triple bracket pairs.
